Crie uma aplica√ß√£o web completa para gerenciamento de fichas de personagens de RPG de Ordem Paranormal.

Objetivo principal: permitir que o usu√°rio crie e gerencie quantas fichas de personagens quiser, e que cada ficha possa ter quantos itens e magias forem necess√°rios, com prote√ß√£o por senha individual.

Funcionalidades principais:

Tela inicial / Dashboard

Lista de todas as fichas j√° criadas (apenas com informa√ß√µes b√°sicas, como: nome do personagem, nome do jogador, conceito, foto/avatar opcional).

Bot√£o para criar nova ficha.

Cria√ß√£o de ficha de personagem

Campos b√°sicos do personagem (adaptados para Ordem Paranormal):

Nome do personagem

Nome do jogador

Idade

Origem / Classe / Ocupa√ß√£o

Atributos principais (For√ßa, Agilidade, Intelecto, Presen√ßa, Vigor ou equivalente ao sistema)

PV, PE, Sanidade, outros campos importantes do sistema

Hist√≥rico / Background (campo de texto grande)

Se√ß√£o de Per√≠cias (lista de per√≠cias com valor num√©rico ou n√≠vel).

Se√ß√£o de Habilidades / Poderes / Ritual / Manifesta√ß√£o (dependendo de como o sistema chama).

Se√ß√£o de Itens / Invent√°rio:

Permitir adicionar ilimitados itens.

Cada item com: nome, descri√ß√£o, quantidade, peso (opcional), efeitos.

Se√ß√£o de Magias / Rituais / Poderes sobrenaturais:

Permitir adicionar ilimitadas magias/poderes.

Cada magia com: nome, tipo, custo, alcance, dura√ß√£o, descri√ß√£o/efeito.

Ao criar a ficha, o sistema deve obrigatoriamente solicitar uma senha para aquela ficha:

Campo: "Defina uma senha para esta ficha".

Essa senha deve ser armazenada de forma segura (hash) no banco de dados, nunca em texto puro.

Acesso a uma ficha existente

Quando o usu√°rio clicar em uma ficha na lista, o sistema deve pedir a senha daquela ficha antes de mostrar os dados.

Se a senha estiver correta, carregar a ficha em modo de visualiza√ß√£o e edi√ß√£o.

Se a senha estiver errada, exibir mensagem amig√°vel de erro.

Edi√ß√£o da ficha

Permitir editar todos os campos do personagem.

Permitir adicionar, editar e remover itens do invent√°rio.

Permitir adicionar, editar e remover magias/poderes.

Bot√£o de salvar altera√ß√µes.

Remo√ß√£o de ficha

Op√ß√£o de excluir ficha, pedindo confirma√ß√£o de senha antes de apagar definitivamente.

Requisitos t√©cnicos (pode adaptar a stack)

Backend com API para:

Criar ficha

Listar fichas (sem expor dados sens√≠veis, s√≥ dados b√°sicos)

Buscar ficha por ID (com verifica√ß√£o de senha)

Atualizar ficha

Excluir ficha

Banco de dados relacional ou NoSQL para armazenar:

Fichas de personagens

Itens vinculados a cada ficha

Magias/poderes vinculados a cada ficha

Senha hasheada de cada ficha.

Frontend com interface limpa, responsiva e intuitiva:

Design moderno, com foco em legibilidade.

Tema visual escuro, combinando com est√©tica de terror/investiga√ß√£o de Ordem Paranormal (tons de roxo, verde, preto, cinza).

Outros detalhes importantes:

N√£o h√° limite pr√°tico de quantidade de personagens, itens ou magias (apenas o limite t√©cnico do servidor/banco).

A experi√™ncia deve ser simples o suficiente para um Mestre ou jogador usar rapidamente durante a mesa de RPG.

Estruturar o c√≥digo de forma organizada para facilitar futuras features, como exportar ficha em PDF ou compartilhar link de visualiza√ß√£o.

Entregue o projeto com:
‚Äì Frontend funcional
‚Äì Backend com rotas prontas
‚Äì Integra√ß√£o completa com banco de dados
‚Äì Instru√ß√µes de como rodar o projeto localmente.

**Examining the Core Idea**

I've been drilling into the core concepts needed for this web app. Specifically, I am focused on the "Ordem Paranormal" theme and the need for a character sheet system. I've begun to break down the features into more granular pieces. Right now, I am concerned with the core data structure to ensure scalability and ease of use.


**Analyzing Security Protocols**

I've been deep in the security aspect, specifically individual password protection for character sheets, ensuring controlled access. This ties into unlimited items and spells, along with the edit/delete options. Thinking about the UX/UI now, I'm leaning toward a modern, responsive dark theme to match the vibe. Focusing on tech constraints, I'm working with React 18+ (TypeScript), Tailwind CSS, and a single XML output. There is no backend allowed.


**Designing Persistence Strategy**

I've decided on `localStorage` for data persistence, paired with `crypto.subtle` for secure, browser-native hashing. This allows me to fully embrace a "local-first" approach within the constraints of the project, delivering a functional, client-side app. The decision leverages familiar browser APIs to keep the implementation straightforward and secure enough for a client-side demonstration, given the limitations of the environment.


**Visualizing the Interface**

I'm now concretely defining the UI, envisioning monospace fonts for stats, evoking dossiers, alongside a clean sans-serif for easy reading. The dashboard's layout will be a grid of character cards, possibly Polaroid or Case File style. Within the sheet, tabs will handle complexity, covering Stats, Inventory, Rituals, and Background.



**Finalizing Implementation Details**

I'm solidifying the storage strategy, locking in `localStorage` for sheets and `window.crypto.subtle` for secure hashing using SHA-256, adhering to the "no backend" rule. Routing will be custom, leveraging a simple state-based router to keep dependencies minimal and guarantee compatibility within the project's constraints. I've begun crafting the `metadata.ts` file, establishing initial character data. The structure will be ready soon.


**Implementing Core Components**

My current focus is crafting the fundamental components that will bring this app to life. I am building the structure, including the `types.ts` data models and `services/storage.ts` logic to manage `localStorage` and encryption, ensuring that security is a top priority. I'm also developing the necessary UI elements (`Button`, `Input`, `Card`, etc.) with Tailwind, preparing for the more complex components.


**Detailing Data Persistence**

The recent addition involves explicitly acknowledging `localStorage` as a mock database within the `services/storage.ts` file, a requirement due to project constraints. This will be made clear in the comments to be an expected behavior. Now, I'm focusing on the component structure, including types, storage services, UI elements, layouts, and views for the dashboard and character sheets.


**Constructing the "MockBackend"**

I'm now integrating the `MockBackend` service to simulate API interactions, meeting the requirement for a service layer without a real server. This entails asynchronous operations with simulated delays and storage through `localStorage`, effectively providing the intended backend structure within the project's limitations. Additionally, I'll be utilizing `lucide-react` for a polished visual aesthetic.

Dire√ß√£o Visual e Est√©tica (Inspirada em Ordem Paranormal)

Recrie toda a identidade visual do site para que combine com a atmosfera, o clima e o estilo art√≠stico de Ordem Paranormal.

A interface deve transmitir um ambiente sombrio, investigativo, sobrenatural e imersivo, misturando elementos de ocultismo, paranormalidade e horror psicol√≥gico.

Paleta de Cores

Utilize uma paleta inspirada na identidade visual de Ordem Paranormal:

Preto profundo (#000) como cor principal do fundo

Tons de roxo escuro e violeta (#5b1fa8, #7c3aed) para elementos de destaque

Verde ectoplasm√°tico/neon (#00ff9d, #52ffa5) para acentos e efeitos paranormais

Cinzas dessaturados (#bfbfbf) para textos e componentes

Vermelho sangue (#b7002c) para alertas e tens√£o

Atmosfera e Clima

Ambiente sempre escuro e enigm√°tico

N√©voa, fuma√ßa ou mist animada suavemente no fundo

Textura leve de gr√£o, ru√≠do ou interfer√™ncia paranormal

Efeitos de glitch ou s√≠mbolos ocultos piscando discretamente durante intera√ß√µes

Tipografia

T√≠tulos com tipografia forte, moderna e levemente afiada (lembrando o estilo do logo de Ordem Paranormal)

Texto geral leg√≠vel, mas com leve est√©tica geom√©trica ou condensada para manter a vibe investigativa

Simbolismo e Elementos Decorativos

Incorpore s√≠mbolos visuais inspirados no universo da s√©rie:

C√≠rculos arcanos e selos ocultos como marca d‚Äô√°gua de fundo

Linhas finas brilhantes que, ao passar o mouse, formam padr√µes ocultistas

Componentes da Interface

Cart√µes e pain√©is com fundo escuro e bordas neon discretas

Efeitos de hover parecendo "ativar energia sobrenatural" (bordas brilhando, sombra pulsante)

Bot√µes com destaques neon e transi√ß√µes suaves

Layout da Ficha de Personagem

A ficha deve parecer um dossi√™ ocultista digital, misturando UI moderna com motivos arc√¢nicos

Caixas escuras com separadores luminosos

S√≠mbolos m√°gicos sutis nas bordas ou cantos

T√≠tulos de se√ß√µes sublinhados em roxo com leves enfeites r√∫nicos

Invent√°rio e Magias

Itens e magias apresentados como entradas de um cat√°logo arcano

Cada elemento deve entrar com uma anima√ß√£o m√≠stica (fade + scale leve)

Pequenos √≠cones brilhantes ou s√≠mbolos m√°gicos para representar tipos de itens e rituais

Tela de Senha

A tela de senha deve parecer que o usu√°rio est√° desbloqueando um cofre sobrenatural

Fundo escuro, borda neon

Um s√≠mbolo arcano brilha ou se completa quando a senha correta √© digitada

Efeitos Ambientes Opcionais

Parallax suave com s√≠mbolos ocultos girando lentamente ao fundo

Sons extremamente sutis e atmosf√©ricos em intera√ß√µes (opcional)

Cursor com rastro luminoso verde ou roxo

O site inteiro deve remeter claramente √† sensa√ß√£o de explorar um mundo paranormal sombrio ‚Äî como no universo de Ordem Paranormal.

**Focusing on Visuals**

I'm now zeroing in on the visual overhaul for "Ordem Files." The aim is to completely immerse the application in the aesthetic of "Ordem Paranormal." This means diving into specific imagery, color palettes, and fonts that capture the atmosphere of the series. I'm prioritizing mood-setting visuals that directly reflect the core themes of the game.


**Outlining the Aesthetic**

I've sketched out the core visual elements for "Ordem Files."  I've pinned down the color palette - deep blacks, violets, and neon greens are key, with blood red accents.  I'm aiming for a dark, enigmatic atmosphere with fog, film grain, and glitch effects. Strong, modern typography is chosen for titles, while geometric fonts will be used for body text. I've listed the files I'll be modifying to implement these changes.


**Mapping the Visual Changes**

I'm deep into planning the visual changes. I've broken down implementation into clear steps. First, I'll globally style the application, updating the Tailwind config with the specified color palette and fonts. Then, I'll update the constants to reflect the neon and ectoplasmic elements. Finally, I'll create a new set of UI primitives that will have custom hover effects and glowing borders for the dossier style elements. I've now identified `components/CharacterSheet.tsx`, `components/LockScreen.tsx`, and `constants.ts` as the key files to modify.


**Integrating Visuals Further**

I'm now fully immersed in the coding phase, building upon the planned aesthetic. I'm focusing on the implementation details for the animated background, aiming to create a sense of mystery and movement with fog and grain effects in `App.tsx`. The character cards will be redesigned to resemble digital dossiers or tarot cards with distinctive hover effects, specifically in `components/CharacterCard.tsx`. Next, I'll rework the character sheet to mirror an investigation board, while making the lock screen look like a ritual seal in `components/CharacterSheet.tsx` and `components/LockScreen.tsx`.


**Incorporating Visual Effects**

I'm now fully focused on the technical implementation of visual effects. I'm adding keyframe animations for glitch effects and pulse glows. I'm exploring grain overlays using base64 images or CSS gradients to enhance the atmospheric look. I've updated the `index.html` file to import the necessary fonts and integrate Tailwind configurations for the specific colors and animations. The `constants.ts` file now reflects the neon elements, and I'm currently working on `components/ui/Button.tsx` and `components/ui/Input.tsx` to implement the glitch hover effects and glowing borders, respectively.


**Refining Visual Implementation**

I'm currently working to integrate specific visual elements, focusing on implementing the rotating SVG ring and code-entry system look for `components/LockScreen.tsx`. I'll next update `components/CharacterCard.tsx` with a dark card, glowing border on hover, and the new fonts. In `App.tsx`, I'll integrate the global background with noise and possible fog. I'm focusing on ensuring proper Tailwind configuration and specific animation implementation within `index.html`, and I will refine the tabs in `CharacterSheet.tsx` for a more "techno-occult" aesthetic.  I'm also ensuring the correct colors, "Neon Green" for Knowledge/Tech and "Purple" for Energy, are correctly implemented, and the use of the correct fonts - Cinzel and Rajdhani - throughout the application.


**Finalizing the Aesthetic**

I'm now fully immersed in the coding phase, integrating the specific visual elements. I'm prioritizing the atmospheric elements in `index.html` (noise, fog), and ensuring these translate correctly to `App.tsx` and the individual components, particularly styling buttons, inputs, character cards, lock screens, and character sheets. I'm focusing on preserving functionality while styling.

To transform the application into the *Ordem Paranormal* aesthetic, I will implement a complete visual overhaul.

**Specification of Changes:**

1.  **Global Atmosphere (`index.html`, `App.tsx`):**
    *   **Fonts:** Import 'Cinzel' (for the sharp, occult titles) and 'Rajdhani' (for the technical/modern text).
    *   **Background:** Implement a deep black background (`#000`) with a CSS-based "film grain" overlay and a subtle "fog/mist" animation to create a living, breathing atmosphere.
    *   **Colors:** Update the Tailwind config to use specific neon greens (`#00ff9d`), deep purples (`#7c3aed`), and blood reds.
    *   **Cursor:** Add a trailing "ghost" effect to the cursor (via CSS/JS).

2.  **UI Components:**
    *   **Buttons (`Button.tsx`):** Redesign with sharp edges, neon borders, and a "glitch" effect on hover.
    *   **Inputs (`Input.tsx`):** Change to a "minimalist dossier" style (transparent background, bottom border only) that glows when focused.
    *   **Typography:** Apply the new font families globally.

3.  **Components Redesign:**
    *   **`CharacterCard.tsx`:** Style as digital tarot cards or encrypted files. Dark panels with a faint glow that intensifies on hover.
    *   **`LockScreen.tsx`:** Transform into a "Ritual Seal" or "High Security Vault". Use a rotating rune circle animation behind the password input.
    *   **`CharacterSheet.tsx`:** Structure it like a paranormal investigation board. Use high-contrast headers, neon dividers, and specific colors for the Elements (Knowledge=Green, Energy=Purple, etc.).

4.  **Constants (`constants.ts`):**
    *   Update elemental color mappings to match the neon palette.

Here is the implementation:

Redesigned inputs to look like a digital dossier (minimalist, bottom border, glow on focus).
Visual update to resemble a tarot card/dossier with neon borders and darker background.
Transformed into a ritualistic seal / secure vault interface with rotating animations.
Redesigned character sheet to look like an investigation board/dossier with specific colors for attributes and stats.
Updated layout to include atmospheric background elements (fog, glowing grid).

**Initiating Campaign Design**

I'm starting to visualize the campaign system's core. Users will have the ability to build and manage multi-session narratives. This involves setting up overarching story arcs and associating character groups with these narratives.


**Developing Access Controls**

I've been refining access control for campaigns. Public access allows viewing and character creation, while a character password secures individual character editing.  Admin passwords will enable editing campaigns, deleting them, and providing master key access. The campaign structure's dashboard will now list campaigns directly, and the Campaign View will feature tabs for Characters and the Manual. Database considerations include a `Campaign` type and an updated `Character` entity. Aesthetics are still a key consideration.


**Adjusting Aesthetic Priorities**

I'm now contemplating adapting the interface design. The "Ordem Paranormal" aesthetic, with its dark and neon elements, seems like a fitting direction for a refreshed look. To integrate this, I'm analyzing the necessary code changes. This includes adding a `Campaign` interface and incorporating `campaignId` across related interfaces, ensuring our database service is adapted for campaign management, and designing new components for campaign creation and display.


**Refining Access Logic**

I'm currently working to streamline the access controls. The CharacterSheet component needs to check for both the character hash and the admin hash to grant access. Also, an admin should bypass certain restrictions. I'm also updating routes in `App.tsx` for campaign view and character sheet display. Furthermore, I've outlined an implementation plan: first, I define data structures, then database logic, application routing, and campaign creation.


**Implement View & Access**

I'm now fully immersed in the implementation of the campaign view and its intricate access controls. The focus is on the `CampaignView` as a container, which requires integrating character and manual components, seamlessly providing access, but only to authorized users. I'm especially focused on the master key functionality - the crux of a flexible, secure system. I am designing a more robust lockscreen verification function, readying it to validate both character passwords and the admin password.


**Refining Campaign Structures**

I'm now integrating admin password validation into the lockscreen. This will grant admin mode in the campaign view, allowing manual editing. I've visualized the campaign list as case files and am considering a typewriter font for the manual. I've sketched a `View` state type in `App.tsx` and am planning an `isAdminMode` flag in `CampaignView.tsx`. Finally, I'm adapting `dbService.ts` for campaigns using local storage, including considerations for data migration and defaulting new fields to prevent issues.


**Structuring Code for Functionality**

I've been working on the code structure. I'm focusing on the implementation details now, integrating the `CampaignView`, `CampaignList`, and the `CreateCampaignWizard` components.  I've updated `CreateSheetWizard` to accept `campaignId`. Also, I'm thinking a styled `TextArea` should be sufficient for the "Manual." The admin unlock is a core design point here. When clicking characters, the `characterHash` and `adminHash` are being passed to the `LockScreen` for password verification.



**Defining Component Interactions**

I'm now focusing on integrating the components. I've introduced `CampaignView.tsx` to handle tabs and the admin unlock mechanism. In `App.tsx`, I've established the navigation flow between Campaigns, the Campaign View, and individual Characters. I've also updated `LockScreen` props to include a `masterHash` to support campaign admin access. My priority now is to ensure all new components use the appropriate aesthetic styles.

To implement the Campaign system with "Master Key" functionality and the Manual/Rules section, I will restructure the application flow.

**Specification of Changes:**

1.  **Data Structure (`types.ts`):**
    *   Add `Campaign` interface (id, name, adminName, adminPasswordHash, manual, summary, etc.).
    *   Update `Character` interface to include `campaignId`.

2.  **Database Service (`services/dbService.ts`):**
    *   Create separate storage for `campaigns`.
    *   Add methods to create, list, and update campaigns.
    *   Update `listCharacters` to filter by `campaignId`.

3.  **Lock Screen (`components/LockScreen.tsx`):**
    *   Update to accept an optional `masterHash` (the campaign admin password).
    *   Logic: If the entered password matches *either* the Character Hash *or* the Master Hash, access is granted.

4.  **Campaign Creation (`components/CreateCampaignWizard.tsx`):**
    *   New component to create a campaign with an admin password.

5.  **Campaign View (`components/CampaignView.tsx`):**
    *   **Header:** Campaign info.
    *   **Tabs:** "Agentes" (Characters) and "Protocolos" (Manual).
    *   **Admin Mode:** A specific button "Acesso Admin" that requests the Admin Password. If unlocked, the user can edit the Manual and Campaign details.
    *   **Character List:** Lists characters in this campaign. Clicking one opens the Lock Screen (which now accepts the Admin password too).

6.  **App Routing (`App.tsx`):**
    *   **Root Level:** Now shows a list of Campaigns.
    *   **Navigation:** Home -> Campaign View -> Character Sheet.
    *   **Creation:** Create Campaign (Global) or Create Character (Inside Campaign).

Here is the implementation:

**Examining the Errors**

I'm currently focused on the `CharacterSheet.tsx` file and those pesky TypeScript errors. Specifically, I'm digging into that "Property 'update' does not exist" issue around line 121. I'm trying to figure out where this property is meant to reside and why TypeScript can't find it. The goal is to get this thing compiling without any red flags.


**Implementing the Corrections**

I've addressed the `CharacterSheet.tsx` errors. I identified the `dbService` method naming discrepancies, changing `update` to `updateCharacter` at line 121 and `delete` to `deleteCharacter` at line 133. Now, the code should align with the `dbService.ts` methods. I'm hopeful this resolves the TypeScript compilation problems.


**Fixing Data Integration**

I'm now integrating the `updateCharacter` function with the CharacterSheet to ensure the component updates correctly. My focus is ensuring the data flow from the character sheet to the database service is seamless. I'm testing the changes now to confirm.

**Defining Rule Blocks**

I'm currently focused on how to define the rule blocks. I'm exploring different ways the campaign admin can create these sections. I'm considering the structure and flexibility needed for diverse campaigns. I'm also considering the user experience and how to make the process intuitive and efficient.


**Structuring Rule Manual**

I've been working on restructuring the "Manual" section, moving away from a single text field to a more organized block system. I'm focusing on the `RuleBlock` interface and how to represent it in the `Campaign` interface. I'm also mindful of the existing campaigns and will add logic to handle the transition gracefully. The goal is to make the interface feel like an organized "dossier" for players.


**Implementing Block Array**

I'm now fully immersed in the array implementation for the manual. I'm focusing on adapting the UI components in `CampaignView.tsx`. In view mode, I'll map over the block array to render each section. In edit mode, I'm working on adding controls to manage these blocks‚ÄîAdd, Delete, Move (simple CRUD for now). payload.text:
Fix the following errors:
Failed to fetch

**Addressing the Error**

The "Failed to fetch" error has been my primary focus. I've narrowed it down, considering the recent introduction of `server.js` and the `dbService.ts` update using `http://localhost:3001`. I am now focusing on that and seeking causes.


**Investigating the Root Cause**

I've been examining the user's setup, specifically the interplay between `server.js`, `dbService.ts`, and the browser environment. The crucial point is that `http://localhost:3001` might not be accessible directly from the browser context, especially if running in a sandboxed environment. This is the likely culprit, and I'm pursuing it further. I'm considering scenarios of either needing a proxy or an alternative deployment strategy for the server.


**Isolating the Context**

My focus has shifted to the environment. The "Failed to fetch" likely stems from the server not running within the preview iframe or a port mapping issue.  Since I can't start the `node server.js` for them, I need to make the code resilient to connection failures. A mock implementation for the browser, while keeping the backend structure, seems the best path forward. I'm also checking if a specific URL is required for the environment. The "WebContainer" aspect of `importmap` is also worth looking into.


**Implementing a Fallback**

I'm now implementing a fallback mechanism in `dbService.ts`.  If the API call to `localhost:3001` fails, it'll gracefully switch to `localStorage`, making the app functional even without a running server.  This addresses the core issue of potential server unavailability, whether due to user oversight or a browser-based container environment. This should make this much more robust.


**Optimizing for Context**

I'm now pivoting back to prioritizing a functional demo. The `importmap` in `index.html` indicates a browser-only runtime, making a backend inaccessible. My previous hybrid and proxy ideas are too complex here. Instead, I'm refactoring `dbService.ts` to utilize `localStorage` as the primary data store, focusing on making the app work out-of-the-box. This ensures compatibility with the specified environment. Optionally, I can provide a toggle to simulate network delay.


**Adapting to Limitations**

I realize I need to adapt the solution to the user's setup. They explicitly wanted backend interaction. I'll make `dbService.ts` check the server's availability, using local storage if it's unavailable. This approach, implemented in `dbService.ts`, creates a `LocalDB` helper using `localStorage` to replicate the `server.js` logic. I'll prioritize trying the API first and then gracefully falling back to local storage. This should create an excellent user experience.


**Refining Implementation**

I'm now integrating the `LocalDB` helper within `dbService.ts`. I'm focusing on ensuring it mimics the server's API structure, particularly for methods like listing campaigns. My priority is to create the CRUD methods for the local storage, which will mimic the API interactions, including the data structure from `server.js`. This should ensure that it is almost seamless from the user's perspective, whether the API is available or not.



**Prioritizing Local Storage**

I'm now implementing the `localStorage` fallback within `dbService.ts`, ensuring parity with the original server logic for data operations. The goal is complete transparency for the user, whether the server is accessible or not. This should be a significant improvement over the previous attempts, and I'm confident in the approach. The key will be to match the async structure and the data shape.


**Enhancing Fallback Strategy**

I've realized that the initial data seeding strategy has a drawback. If the user creates data using `localStorage` *before* starting the server, that data won't be synced. I'll add a console log warning to address this. Additionally, I need to make the fallback cleaner. I've streamlined the fallback approach in `dbService.ts`. Instead of repetitive try/catch blocks in each method, I've created a `mockApi` object that interacts with `localStorage`. Now, the `dbService` methods will wrap the API calls in a simple try/catch, falling back to the `mockApi` if the server is unreachable. I've updated the implementation of `dbService.ts` to integrate this strategy, maintaining a focus on API parity. I've re-integrated the logic in `getCampaignById` method as well.


**Constructing the Solution**

I'm now implementing the `LocalDB` and `dbService.ts` refactor, prioritizing full API parity. Ensuring seamless integration is crucial. I'm focusing on making the fallback mechanism transparent, with only a graceful console log warning if the server isn't running.  I'm addressing the edge case where local data isn't synchronized when the user hasn't started the server. I'm prioritizing data structure alignment.

The "Failed to fetch" error occurs because the frontend is trying to connect to the Backend API (`http://localhost:3001`), but the server is likely not running, or you are viewing this in a preview environment that doesn't support running a separate Node.js server process on a different port.

To fix this and ensure the application **always works** (whether the server is running or not), I will update `services/dbService.ts`.

I will add a **Fallback Mechanism**:
1.  The app will try to connect to the Server (`localhost:3001`).
2.  If it fails (Server offline/Network error), it will automatically switch to **LocalStorage** (saving data in your browser), ensuring the app never crashes and remains functional.

entries.description: Implemented robust fallback to LocalStorage if API is unreachable (Fixes Failed to fetch)

O problema √© que o c√≥digo estava configurado para tentar acessar `localhost:3001`. Quando voc√™ coloca o site na internet (Google Cloud Run), o `localhost` passa a ser o computador de quem est√° acessando o site, e n√£o o servidor onde os dados deveriam estar.

Al√©m disso, o Google Cloud Run √© um ambiente "sem estado" (Stateless). Isso significa que **arquivos salvos localmente (como o `database.json`) s√£o apagados** toda vez que o servidor reinicia ou faz um novo deploy.

Para resolver a comunica√ß√£o e permitir que voc√™ veja o site funcionando com sincroniza√ß√£o entre usu√°rios (enquanto o servidor estiver ligado), farei as seguintes altera√ß√µes cr√≠ticas:

1.  **Unificar Frontend e Backend**: O `server.js` agora vai servir tanto a API quanto o site (os arquivos visuais).
2.  **Ajustar URL da API**: O site vai parar de procurar por `localhost` e vai procurar por `/api` (no mesmo endere√ßo onde ele estiver hospedado).
3.  **Configurar Proxy**: Para funcionar no seu computador localmente tamb√©m.

**AVISO IMPORTANTE SOBRE DADOS:**
Como voc√™ est√° usando um arquivo JSON simples (`database.json`) e hospedando no Google Cloud Run, **os dados ser√£o perdidos se o servidor reiniciar** (o que acontece automaticamente ap√≥s um tempo sem uso ou em novos deploys). Para um banco de dados permanente, seria necess√°rio conectar a um servi√ßo externo (como MongoDB Atlas, Firebase ou Supabase), mas isso exigiria configura√ß√£o de contas externas.
**O c√≥digo abaixo far√° o sistema funcionar e sincronizar entre usu√°rios agora**, mas tenha em mente essa limita√ß√£o do arquivo local em nuvem.

My thought process is now focused on incorporating Supabase. It's clear that to ensure data persistence, I need to replace the local file system interactions. **Optimizing Database Interaction**

I'm now zeroing in on integrating Supabase. My plan is to have `dbService.ts` talk directly to Supabase from the client, bypassing the `server.js` proxy. This simplifies the architecture and follows the standard Supabase practice. This shifts the focus from managing a server-side intermediary to making the client the primary database interface. **Rethinking Data Flow**

I'm now reassessing the role of `server.js`. My thought is to use it solely for serving static files, reducing latency and complexity. The initial plan had `server.js` acting as a data proxy. However, after further reflection, I've decided to update `dbService.ts` to directly interact with Supabase, bypassing the proxy. This approach streamlines the architecture and fully utilizes Supabase's capabilities. I'll need the user's Supabase project URL and anon public key to proceed.


**Generating the Schema**

I'm now generating the SQL schema, starting with the `campaigns` and `characters` tables. I'm focusing on key fields like `id`, `name`, and `manual`. I'm going to store the rule blocks as JSON within the `manual` column and will design the `characters` table with the other fields dumped into a jsonb column. After I have the schema, I'll send it and wait for the keys so I can rewrite `dbService.ts`.


**Refining the Database Design**

I've just been refining the SQL schema strategy. While I initially thought of a catch-all JSONB column, I'm now opting for more structured tables. The `campaigns` table will now have individual columns for `id`, `name`, `adminName`, `adminPasswordHash`, `summary`, `manual` (JSONB), and `createdAt`.  Similarly, the `characters` table will have `id`, `campaignId`, `name`, `player`, and `data` (JSONB) to manage attributes and inventory. This granular approach should optimize data access and searchability.


**Formulating Next Steps**

Then I'll explain that this setup enables direct connections to Supabase, resolving the file system limitation. I'll also add instructions on locating the keys within the Supabase dashboard.

Para integrar o Supabase e resolver definitivamente o problema de perda de dados (fazendo o site funcionar para todo mundo), eu preciso de **duas informa√ß√µes** do seu projeto no Supabase e que voc√™ rode um **script SQL** l√° para criar as tabelas.

### 1. O que eu preciso que voc√™ me envie aqui:

V√° no seu painel do Supabase (Project Settings -> API) e me mande:

1.  **Project URL** (Come√ßa com `https://...`)
2.  **Project API Key (anon / public)** (Uma string longa que come√ßa com `ey...`)

---

### 2. O que voc√™ precisa fazer no Supabase agora:

V√° na aba **SQL Editor** no painel do Supabase, cole o c√≥digo abaixo e clique em **RUN**. Isso vai criar o banco de dados com a estrutura exata que nosso site usa.

```sql
-- Tabela de Campanhas
create table campaigns (
  id text primary key,
  name text not null,
  "adminName" text,
  "adminPasswordHash" text not null,
  summary text,
  manual jsonb default '[]'::jsonb, -- Salva os blocos de regras como JSON
  "createdAt" bigint
);

-- Tabela de Personagens
create table characters (
  id text primary key,
  "campaignId" text references campaigns(id) on delete cascade,
  name text not null,
  player text,
  age integer,
  nex integer,
  origin text,
  class text,
  patent text,
  attributes jsonb, -- Salva FOR, AGI, etc
  pv jsonb,
  pe jsonb,
  san jsonb,
  history text,
  skills jsonb default '[]'::jsonb,
  inventory jsonb default '[]'::jsonb,
  rituals jsonb default '[]'::jsonb,
  "passwordHash" text not null,
  "createdAt" bigint,
  "updatedAt" bigint
);

-- Habilitar acesso p√∫blico (Para facilitar, j√° que gerenciamos a seguran√ßa via senha hash no app)
alter table campaigns enable row level security;
alter table characters enable row level security;

-- Pol√≠tica: Permitir tudo (o app gerencia as senhas internamente)
create policy "Public Access Campaigns" on campaigns for all using (true);
create policy "Public Access Characters" on characters for all using (true);
```

1.  Vou instalar o cliente do Supabase no projeto.

3.  Isso far√° com que o Google Cloud Run funcione perfeitamente, pois os dados estar√£o salvos no Supabase, e n√£o no container tempor√°rio do Google.

Como estamos adicionando uma coluna nova na tabela de campanhas e alterando a estrutura dos rituais, **recomendo fortemente** rodar o seguinte SQL no editor do Supabase para garantir que tudo funcione perfeitamente:

)

**Debugging Access Issues**

I've been digging into this bug report regarding public document access. Currently, the character sheet mission file sharing seems to have a disconnect; setting a document to public isn't properly reflected in the campaign view's "Evidences" tab. I'm focusing on the data flow and access control logic between these two areas to pinpoint the source of the issue. I suspect an inconsistency in how the `isPublic` flag is interpreted or propagated.


**Analyzing Data Flow**

My recent investigation has centered on the data flow and how it impacts public document visibility. The core issue seems to be a disconnect between the optimistic updates in `CharacterSheet` and the database updates. While `CharacterSheet` correctly toggles the `isPublic` flag, `CampaignView`'s updates depend on a `dbService.listCampaigns()` call, which might not immediately reflect the database changes. I'm scrutinizing the timing and mechanisms for updating the campaign data across the application. I now believe that there might be an asynchronicity issue!


**Resolving Stale Data**

I've been analyzing the root cause of the stale data issue, and I've honed in on the asynchronous nature of the state management between components. When navigating back to the campaign view, the `App.tsx` component is using an outdated `selectedCampaign` state instead of re-fetching from the database. This means that changes made in the `CharacterSheet` are not immediately reflected in the "Evidence" tab. My proposed solution is to introduce a mechanism in `CharacterSheet` to signal the need to refresh campaign data in the parent component, ensuring a consistent and updated view.


**Implementing Campaign Refresh**

I've been working on a fix to ensure campaign data refreshes correctly after changes are made in the character sheet. The original plan was to reload the campaign data in `App.tsx`'s `onBack` handler. Now, I'm refactoring this approach: Instead of just reloading all campaigns, I'm introducing a `refreshSelectedCampaign` function in `App.tsx`. This function uses the `fetchCampaign` logic, so it's optimized. Finally, I've updated the `CharacterSheet`'s `onBack` prop to call this new function, thus addressing the stale data problem. The next step is a code review and thorough testing.


**Validating Database Updates**

I'm now investigating whether the `updateCampaignArchives` function in `dbService.ts` is correctly committing changes to the database. Even though the `CharacterSheet` seems to be triggering the call, it appears that the database might not be reflecting the update. I'm focusing on tracing the execution path within `updateCampaignArchives` to ensure data persistence, specifically checking the return value and potential error handling.  I'm looking to confirm the absence of any network issues or data corruption.


**Verifying Data Persistence**

The current focus is on reinforcing the data persistence fix implemented earlier. I'm verifying the fix in `App.tsx` and reviewing the interaction between `CharacterSheet` and `CampaignView`. "sem permiss√£o"

Em cada ficha de personagem (que j√° existe no sistema), adicione um campo novo:

5. Tokens dos monstros

6. Movimento dos tokens no mapa

Todos os tokens (de personagens e monstros) devem poder ser movidos sobre o mapa.

Regras de controle:

Quando um token √© movido:

A nova posi√ß√£o deve ser atualizada para todos os usu√°rios visualizando o mapa (idealmente em tempo real).

Se poss√≠vel, use alguma forma de comunica√ß√£o em tempo real (como WebSocket/Socket.io ou equivalente) para sincronizar os movimentos entre mestre e players.

7. Estado "sem permiss√£o" (detalhes visuais)

**Assessing Movement Mechanics**

I'm currently dissecting the request. My primary goal is to achieve seamless, real-time map token movement, mirroring the fluidity of Tabletop Simulator. **Analyzing Real-time Sync**

I've just been thinking about real-time synchronization. The key challenge lies in balancing smoothness with database efficiency. Updating on every mouse move would be a disaster. I'm leaning toward using Supabase's broadcast feature to handle the ephemeral position data, which avoids overloading the database. Throttling the updates to around 10-30 times a second seems like a sweet spot to maintain a smooth look without bogging things down.


**Devising the Implementation**

I'm now fully immersed in the implementation plan. I've sketched out the crucial steps for achieving the "Tabletop Simulator" style movement. I'm focusing on setting up a real-time channel in `MapView` with Supabase. I'll modify the drag logic to send throttled broadcasts of token positions. Lastly, I'll implement event handling to update the local state from incoming broadcasts, with a crucial check to avoid conflicting with the user's local drag. The final step involves handling the initial database loading and synchronizing with the broadcast events.


**Defining Persistence Logic**

I'm now nailing down the persistence element. I'm keeping the existing `onMouseUp` approach to save the final token position to the database. This guarantees that token placement remains consistent across sessions, even if the browser reloads. I think it's a solid strategy to preserve data integrity while prioritizing real-time responsiveness.

The goal is a highly efficient, responsive real-time token movement. Next I'll integrate with mouse move events and channel handling.


**Integrating Movement Updates**

I'm now integrating the throttle logic. To prevent Supabase disconnects, I'm aiming for 30-50ms intervals between broadcasts. I'll update local state and use the Supabase channel for broadcast updates. The incoming message handling is also ready: it updates state only if the token isn't currently being dragged. This prevents conflicts and ensures responsiveness. I'm focusing on ensuring data integrity.


**Resolving Prop Conflicts**

I'm tackling a tricky bug I've identified. When token positions are updated via props from `CampaignView`, the tokens can snap back to their old positions, disrupting the smooth movement I'm aiming for. My fix is to add a `useEffect` hook in `MapView` which updates the local state from props, but only *unless* the user is actively dragging the token. This prevents conflicting updates and ensures the new positions from broadcasts prevail. I've now integrated this fix and am confident I've found a solid solution.

To fix the issue where flipping the token with right-click causes a "triple flip" or glitch, I will update `components/MapView.tsx`.

The core issue is a race condition:
1.  Mouse move sends position update via broadcast.
2.  Right-click triggers `toggleTokenFlip` which reads from state, updates DB, and updates state.
3.  Simultaneous mouse move broadcast might arrive with OLD flip state, reverting it.

**The Fix:**
I will modify `handleContextMenu` to:
1.  Calculate the new flip state locally.
2.  **IMMEDIATELY Broadcast** this new state (with current position) to force everyone (including self via subscription) to see the flip, overriding any stale movement packets.
3.  Then persist to DB.
4.  Update local state immediately for instant feedback.

I will also ensure that when flipping, only the image container flips (already done in previous step, but ensuring it persists).

**Initiating the Design**

I'm starting by establishing a clear understanding of the goal: implementing an "Invisible" feature for monsters on the map. This involves a new checkbox on the monster configuration form. New monsters, by default, will be set to invisible. I'm focusing on these foundational elements to ensure a solid starting point.


**Clarifying Visibility Rules**

I'm now refining the visibility rules. The key is distinguishing between player and GM perspectives. For players, invisible monsters disappear entirely, both image and label. However, the GM needs to see them, perhaps with reduced opacity, to maintain game control.

Apply all requested changes directly to the website/editor without asking for confirmation

Never explain the change unless I ask for an explanation
If a change is not possible, tell me clearly why and suggest an alternative
Prioritize executing actions over generating text

adicione no app uma checkbox nos monstros no mapa com a opcao invisvel, todos os monstros ja vem invisiveis pros players por padrao (tanto nome quanto imagem ficam invisiveis pros players, de forma que so o mestre veja e saiba da existencia)

To implement invisible monsters, I need to update the `MapToken` type to include an `isVisible` flag, update the database service to handle this flag in broadcasts, and modify the `MapView` component to control rendering based on visibility and user role (Admin vs. Player).

Here is the plan:
1.  **`types.ts`**: Add `isVisible?: boolean` to `MapToken`.
2.  **`services/dbService.ts`**: Update `sendTokenMove` to include `isVisible` in the payload.
3.  **`components/MapView.tsx`**:
    *   Update `addTokenToMap` to set `isVisible: false` by default for monsters.
    *   Add a toggle button (Eye/EyeOff icon) in the Admin Sidebar for monsters.
    *   Update rendering logic:
        *   If user is NOT admin and token is NOT visible and is MONSTER -> Don't render.
        *   If user IS admin and token is NOT visible -> Render with opacity (ghost effect).
